utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Did I say anything stupid? I had two drinks! Three! Okay, there was that last one.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: That’s okay, some day you’ll be pregnant and you can return the favor.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: I feel like such an idiot sometimes.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Oh!

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: You know, when the baby comes –

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: You know what? You are going to be so great. You are.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: You all right?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Uh, uh huh. Oh, no.

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: You know why I pulled you over?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I - I’m so sorry, Officer, I must have, uh, dozed off.

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: Have you been drinking?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Of course she hasn’t.

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: Somebody has.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: I’ve been drinking. You all right?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I, I’m not, I, uh –

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: How far along are you?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Uh, almost, um –

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: Ma’am, step out of the vehicle. Ma’am, walk to the rear of the car.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Naomi, are you… Naomi? Naomi –

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: Sir, remain in the car!

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Hey, listen, she’s not drunk, all right?

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: I will arrest you, sir.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: She’s sick!

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: Badge 302, could you roll me another unit?

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: She’s not looking –

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: Get back in the car.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Naomi! Call an ambulance!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, the good news is, it doesn’t look like a stroke. No bleeds, no clots.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Thank God.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: It sounds like there’s bad news.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We got your blood work back. Some things are a little off. Your liver and kidneys aren’t working so well.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Why, what would cause that?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: It’s preeclampsia, isn’t it? I’m gonna miscarry, aren’t I?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Preeclampsia is a possibility, but let’s not get ahead of ourselves.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I’ve miscarried three times, I’m 39, we had to use in vitro, you’ve gotta make sure that the baby’s okay –

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Let’s make sure that you’re okay, first.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How about we take care of both of you at the same time. The nurse will be in soon to draw some blood; I’d like to run some more tests.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Thank you, Doctor.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Where is everybody?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No one’s in the office?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, haven’t heard from Cameron all day. You seen House?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Heh. Look for a shallow grave with Vogler standing over it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have a Stage 4 cancer. It’s metastasized to your liver. There’s a new drug called 8C 12 that’s shown promise in Phase 2 trials. It’s your best shot.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Thank you, Doctor. You’ve been so good to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I did publicly bash your company’s drug.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: When I think about how I treated you…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, hey, come on. There, there, there.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: So, um, there is some hope?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Always. But just in case, I special-order an extra jumbo-size coffin.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t thank me. It’s just who I am.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Up and at ‘em, big guy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, up late. Internet porn.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How come you’re not in your office?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because there is a computer in my office. If I log on, romance will ensue. My wrist might fall off.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hiding because Vogler’s looking for you. That’s just pathetic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t like loud, angry giants threatening me with violence. How is that pathetic?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You think you can avoid firing one of us by hiding out here? He’ll find you sooner or later.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m okay with later.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: 39-year-old female, 28 weeks pregnant, G 4, P 0.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Three miscarriages? Gimme.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Altered mental status and complete loss of coordination.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tox screen?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Negative for alcohol and drugs. She was on oxybutynin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: For incontinence.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We took her off, but no change. BUN, creatinine are up, LFT slightly elevated.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Preeclampsia. Call the OB-GYN service and rub some prayer beads.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: BP’s normal; no preeclampsia in other pregnancies.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Because she didn’t carry long enough.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The three miscarriages make me think it’s an underlying physiology.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pregnancy-related autoimmunity. Too bad that Cameron quit, I could use an immunologist right now. We’ll see if you’re right; check the blood.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cameron quit?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Last night. And do an MRA for vasculitis, too.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There is no way she quit! She got fired because you couldn’t swallow your pride!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: An ultrasound? Excellent thought! And put her on magnesium, too, in case it is preeclampsia.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Here, pussy, pussy, pussy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I didn’t do anything.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Exactly my point.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You wanted me to yell at him? What the hell would that have achieved? What, is he going to jump into his time machine and fix everything?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: When a dog dumps on the floor, do you pat its head and call it a genius? No, you smack it in the nose with a newspaper!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Dogs can learn things, House can’t.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Coward.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Child.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, there! I brought my colleague along to help out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hi, I’m Dr. Chase.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, ultrasound looks good. No sign of fetal distress.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: So it’s not preeclampsia?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, it still could be, but it hasn’t progressed, at least. We’re gonna put you on bed rest and monitor the baby.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll give you some potassium and magnesium as well. So, we should keep the fluids running for now and check her again in an hour unless there are signs of fetal distress or –

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Honey? Wha – uh, she’s choking!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Lean forward.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: What is, is she all right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s probably just some muscle weakness.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: What do you mean, probably?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Naomi, open up.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: People choke, it could be nothing. You all right?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I can’t, I can’t, I can’t even swallow.

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: She gets sick a lot but this, this cold got really bad all of a sudden. And the fever… Shhhh, it’s okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not a cold. It’s pneumonia.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Pneumonia?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax, pneumonia’s her second-biggest problem. She has gone from the twenty-fifth weight percentile to the third in one month. Now, I’m not a baby expert but I’m pretty sure they’re not supposed to shrink.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Well, there’s this diet we put her on when we stopped breastfeeding –

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: But it’s healthy, raw food. We’re vegans. Almond milk, tofu, vegetables…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Raw food. If only her ancestors had mastered the secret of fire. Babies need fat, proteins, calories. Less important: sprouts and hemp. Starving babies is bad, and illegal in many cultures. I’m having her admitted.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Is she gonna be all right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Antibiotics for the pneumonia, IV feeding to get the weight up. Don’t worry, it’s a vegan IV.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don’t see any signs of vasculitis. Odd, since you’re always right about everything.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be a different auto-immunity. Or you could bite me.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Oh, no.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Naomi, you okay?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I’m getting cramps.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Strong?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Yeah. Feels like my miscarriage.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s preterm labor.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: He’s too little, he won’t survive!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s on magnesium already.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fuse interbutoline, then. We’re going to give you some medicine, okay? Try to stop your labor.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whoa! There you are, I’ve been looking everywhere for you. Uh, listen, you said I had to cut one of my people if I didn’t give that speech about your drug, and in fairness to your point of view, my speech really wasn’t the one you had in mind, so I’ve cut Cameron. Now we’re all squared away, right?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: In the morning, I expect you in my office with your letter of resignation and plans for a public apology, otherwise I’ll destroy you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So that’s a ‘no’ on us being squared away.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She might make it to full term. Contractions are less frequent and not well organized.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Great to see you back in the office. I guess Vogler found you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, we had a nice little chat. I really should have kept Cameron. She knew where to find the sugar.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s what I said. Preeclampsia. A little stress from the MRA, she pops straight into labor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ah ha!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about the myasthenia?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Come on, she didn’t seem that weak.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She choked, she couldn’t even swallow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did she choke on?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her food. The muscle weakness isn’t a symptom of preeclampsia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What kind of food?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A little bit of cooked pear, it doesn’t matter! It shows weakness.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She choked on soft, wet pear. Did she forget to take the bones out? That’s way past muscle weakness. Did you do an upper endoscopy?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You think there’s something obstructing her esophagus?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We’ve gotta talk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oooh. We’ve gotta talk. And check her eyelids.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Check her eyelids?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Special board meeting today, only one item on the agenda: you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, enjoy the bagels. I’m untouchable.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Huh. Right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any vote to revoke my tenure has to be unanimous. I’ve got you and maybe even Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, well that settles it. Mr. Ruthless Corporate Raider will be stymied, go home, curl up on the floor of his shower and weep.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What can he do? I’ve got a contract.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Does it say how much your team gets paid? Where your parking space is? If your car should be filled with horse manure? Vogler’s smart; he’s got some plan to get you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does it involve candy? Because I’m a sucker for chocolates.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s doing better.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Oh, thank God.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Technically, Alexander Fleming. He developed antibiotics. Pneumonia’s under control, and from now on, what say you stick with human food.

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: Absolutely, swear to God.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This time, that’s your guy.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: Officer
utterance.content: You’re under arrest. You have the right to remain silent…

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: What did we do?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: What? How? We –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is how Vogler’s gonna destroy me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What did he do, grease your cane?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He had my patients arrested.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He didn’t, I did. The nurses were concerned and they called me. There was evidence of abuse; you took a big legal risk by not calling Social Services.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Those parents were not abusive, they’re idiots.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, well that’s certainly a relief.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It was my call.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You made the wrong one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know, there’s a new biography of Quisling, I think you might like it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Sure. No idea who that is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh, Norwegian guy, World War II, traitor. The fact that I have to explain this kind of takes the edge off my flow.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was protecting you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: From what? Cops aren’t gonna bust me. Disiplinary committee maybe gives me a slap on the wrist.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And Vogler has an excuse to get rid of you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I don’t give him one, he makes one up.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Vogler’s just one vote; he’s gotta convince the other eleven of us. I’m just trying to stop you from making that extra easy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sean, do your wife’s eyelids look any different than usual?

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Um, maybe one is drooping a little bit, but you know, she’s tired, so…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Naomi, can you open your mouth for me and tilt your head back? This is gonna be a little uncomfortable. Yeah, there’s swelling, indenting the esophagus.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Is that why she choked?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’ll need to do an x-ray.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: What? No, the baby – you said no x-rays.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s important.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Three centimeter mass in her right upper lobe.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Maybe it’s a granuloma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. There’s no calcification.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s small-cell lung cancer. The tumor’s starting to press against your esophagus. It hasn’t metastasized, but it has spread to other parts of your lungs so we can’t operate.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Wait, that doesn’t make sense. She had kidney failure and brain problems…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Some cancer patients get what are called paraneoplastic syndromes. You were making antibodies to fight the tumor. It attacked other cells: your brain first, then your liver, kidneys… even the nerves that control your eyelids. That’s called Lambert-Eaton syndrome, it told us the tumor was in the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: How bad is it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Small-cell is the most aggressive kind of lung cancer. The five-year survival rate is only about ten to fifteen percent, which is why we need to start you on chemo and radiation right away.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Not radiation, what about the baby?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’ll need a C-section before you can start the treatment; I can get you in first thing tomorrow morning.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: What are the chances my baby will survive?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Pretty good. Twenty-eight weeks, so about eighty percent.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: No, wait, that’s one in five chance he’ll die?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I really wouldn’t advise waiting.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Naomi, you’ve got to start this treatment right away –

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: What happens if I wait?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Twenty-nine weeks, survival rate is closer to ninety percent.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I’m not doing the radiation.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: You’ll die –

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Listen, you know the chances, they’re nothing, but a few more weeks will save the baby.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Listen, you’re depressed right now, and you’re not thinking right.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Sweetie –

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Could you just, tell her, please?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This cancer moves quick. The median survival’s two to four months. If you postpone, even for a week…

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I’m sorry, honey.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: As most of you know, Gregory House recently gave a speech about me. I’d like to return the favor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Dr. Wilson. I was hoping you were going to miss this one. A man is the sum of his actions. Here are a few of Dr. House’s. He violated a DNR and was charged with assault. He brought a termite into the OR and spat on a surgeon. He accepted a Corvette from a patient who was a known member of the New Jersey mafia.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Edward.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: These are the last three months. He’s personally had more complaints filed against him than any department in this hospital.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay, he’s screwed up. He’s miserable, and he should probably reread the Ethics Code, but it works for him. He’s saved hundreds of lives.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: He is a drug addict who flaunts his addiction and refuses to get treatment. He is a disgrace and an embarrassment to this hospital. I’d go on, but it gets kinda mean, so I’m gonna keep this simple. House goes, or I go.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You shouldn’t personalize this.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: And by I, I mean my $100 million. How’s that for personalizing?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You gave us that money for a reason. Are you really willing to throw it all away because of one doctor?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Gregory House is a symbol of everything wrong with the healthcare industry. Waste, insubordination, doctors preening like they’re kings and the hospital their own private fiefdom. Healthcare is a business, I’m gonna run it like one. I hereby move to revoke the tenure of Dr. Gregory House and terminate his employment at this hospital, effective immediately.

utterance.speaker: Female Doctor
utterance.content: Don’t you think we should discuss this –

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: We just did.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We need time.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: The vote is on the table. All in favor? Dr. Wilson?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Opposed?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: The motion is defeated. Dr. Wilson, would you mind leaving the room, please?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: We’re gonna take another vote.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, first of all, you can’t void my vote by making me stand in the hallway. And second, you should check the by-laws. You need notice and at least one business day before you can reconsider any matter.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: We’re voting on a different matter which you are… conflicted out of.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How can I be conflicted?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: This vote is whether to dismiss Dr. James Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Naomi is refusing to have the C-section. Her odds aren’t good enough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They do suck. Where’s Wilson?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Paged him twice.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She does this, she knows she’s gonna die.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s saving her child. Cameron would point out that people are capable of sacrifice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cameron isn’t here.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Perhaps proving her point.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think this woman is making a rational decision?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I think people can overcome their baser drives.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pretty damn rarely. And not this time, this is purely biological. In evolutionary terms, the needs of the next generation are more important.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’re saying she’s making the right call?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Darwin is, I’m not. The next generation is not my patient. We have to raise the odds for Mommy. And where the hell is Wilson? He’s the oncologist.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Good plan, cure cancer. Surprised no one ever thought of that before.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: There he is. Dr. House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You guys bust out?

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: We made bail. They won’t let us in our baby’s room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Weird. You’d think they’d let you take her home while they figured out if you tried to kill her.

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: We’re good parents, we fed her whenever she was hungry.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Big meals. We had no idea that diet was so bad for her.

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: The nutritionist said it had everything she needed!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The kid who stacks the free-range grapefruit in your health food store is not a nutritionist.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: But my uncle is. He went to college and everything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman, I need a CT scan on…

utterance.speaker: Joel
utterance.content: Olive Kaplan.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seriously? Olive Kaplan. Check for abscesses or occult infections. Bu-bye.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Listen, Vogler’s all about clinical trials, the hospital’s chock full of them. There’s got to be something for small-cell lung cancer. What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I got sacked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you make a pass at Cuddy? Told you, she only has thighs for me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I voted to keep you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So he’s getting rid of every board member who votes to keep me around?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, every one of us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you’re only off the board, right? They couldn’t have got unanimous approval for you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Brown from Oncology voted no, so did Cuddy, Taylor and Peevey.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eh, so you’re off the board, big deal. Frees up Wednesday nights for bowling. You’re still a doctor –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, getting dumped looks great in Who’s Who. Vogler gave me the option of resigning, and I took it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Big of him.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ve got no kids, my marriage sucks; I’ve only got two things that work for me: this job and this stupid, screwed-up friendship, and neither mattered enough to you to give one lousy speech.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They mattered. If I could do it all again –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’d do the same thing. Well, you’ll be gone soon, too.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Those clinical trials?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ll make some calls.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: It’s not gonna kill me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s hemorrhoids.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: But all that blood… that can’t be right?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Looks worse than it is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nice job of protecting me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Can this wait?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His ass can wait. You saved my job by sacking Wilson?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What did you think would happen when you made that speech? You think he would just pout for a little while and we’d all forgive you? You don’t spit on the man who signs your paycheck. First Cameron, then Wilson – you’re next. Pull your pants up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So it’s about the money.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Of course it’s about the money. The money Vogler gave, he could have bought a few jets, maybe a baseball team, or just stuck it in Chase Manhattan and collected interest. But he gave it to us to buy equipment, to do research! You are a great doctor, House, but you are not worth $100 million.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’ve sequenced the DNA of the tumor cells. P53 gene mutation at codon 55. She’s perfect for your trial.

utterance.speaker: Prather
utterance.content: She’s pretty far advanced.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, you want easy cases, you picked the wrong speciality.

utterance.speaker: Prather
utterance.content: Otherwise in good health?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excellent.

utterance.speaker: Prather
utterance.content: When can she start?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Middle of next week.

utterance.speaker: Prather
utterance.content: Cancer’s already stage 3, it’d be a waste of time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She can start in two days.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She can’t start in two days! She’s pregnant!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She won’t be in two days. I’ve scheduled a C-section.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’d still have to wait a month. You can’t take part in an trials until 30 days after major sugery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, it’s definitely surgery, but major?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not your call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Again, a question of interpretation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’re scamming a doctor, now? Come on, Vogler’s looking for any excuse to can you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, I think he’s got a big bag of those already.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: These regulations aren’t just here to annoy you, okay? Doing this is dangerous to the patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I’ll be sure to let her know that. Care to join me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Angiogenesis inhibitors prevent the tumors from creating blood vessels. Without blood, the tumor starves.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: That sounds great –

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: What about the baby?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The treatment would be fatal to the baby. I’ve scheduled a C-section for later this afternoon. It’s in the trial phase right now, but so far complete remission in more than thirty percent of subjects.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I told Dr. Foreman I didn’t want a C-section.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When your chances of living were less than a third of what they are now.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Well, the baby’s premature, that –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Our pediatrics department has the best neonatal ICU in the state.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: No, his lungs, his brain, he’s not ready.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: And he could be fine!

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: You don’t know what it’s like, raising a sick child!

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: His odds are much better than yours are. You have to let them at least try this. Talk to her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. Leave the room. How long have you been taking oxybutynin?

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Uh, since I was about twenty.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Incontinence is pretty uncommon in a woman of your age. It’s even more bizarre in a woman in her twenties.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I guess I haven’t had the best luck when it comes to my health.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seems that way. You said to your husband, “You don’t know what it’s like, raising a sick child.” You didn’t say, “You don’t know what it would be like.” This is not your first child, is it? And he doesn’t know.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I was eighteen. Got pregnant, got married. I had the most beautiful little girl, Grace. She had infantile Alexander’s disease.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: For two years we watched her die. My husband was, uh, my first husband was a, a great guy, but after that I couldn’t even look at him without thinking of her. I left him, I left my job, I left everything –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Very moving story. Explains why you’re being so selfish.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: I’m willing to die to protect my husband.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because it’s what you want. Your husband wants you to live.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Well, he doesn’t understand…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, who the hell does? Tragedies happen. You think that turning yourself into a disposable incubator for a few weeks is going to protect your baby from all the crap in this world, go ahead, die happy. I got no problems with people killing themselves, but don’t think it makes you a hero.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re scheduled for 4 P.M.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Yes, this is Dr. Lim.

utterance.speaker: Anesthesiologist
utterance.content: Count down from ten.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: Okay. Ten… nine… eight…

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: That seemed kind of fast, is she all right?

utterance.speaker: Anesthesiologist
utterance.content: She’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Wake her up. That was Vogler; surgery’s off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: HEY! You’re killing her!

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Really? See, I thought you were the one trying to ram her into a drug trial five minutes after surgery –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She knows the risks, she was fully informed –

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Well, the guy running the study sure wasn’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not his life, not his call!

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: His study, his call!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, so she kicks off, his number look bad.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: The numbers look bad, the study looks bad!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which would cost you money!

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: And keep a life-saving protocol off the market!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: One person, one blip in the data!

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: You ever heard of the FDA? They eat blips for breakfast! One person should never endanger thousands!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, thank God you were here to save all those lives!

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: The board’s meeting again this evening. Why don’t you settle down? Play some Game Boy. Why don’t you watch your soap? I hear they’re firing the handsome doctor today, boy, that should be a good one.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: If we had the C-section anyway, we could still do the experimental treatment, right? We’d just have to wait thirty days.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Assuming the doctor running the trial isn’t too pissed off to let her in, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Naomi
utterance.content: And assuming I’m even healthy enough to –

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Honey? Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Stats are dropping. Down to the 80s. Stay with us, Naomi.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We need you to leave the room.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Respiratory distress.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Could you just tell me what’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re trying to find out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Still kicking.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Flash pulmonary edema?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Lungs are clear. There it is.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pulmonary embolus.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Gotta get her to an OR.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s an embolism. A blood clot. It’s fairly common with lung cancer. It’s not a full saddle embolism, so blood’s still trickling through. We’ve been able to get Naomi breathing a little, but we need to remove the clot, and we need you to approve the treatment.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Yeah, whatever you have to do, just do it!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not that simple, okay. The best course for the baby would be an immediate C-section. The longer we postpone, the greater chance it’ll have brain damage from lack of oxygen.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Fine, whatever, just do it!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Here’s the problem. The C-section would be very, very dangerous for Naomi.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Dangerous, like…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: In her current condition, there’s a real chance she wouldn’t survive. I’m sorry. Look, your wife’s unconscious, we need you to make a decision.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: I just want her to live. No C-section.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Stats are still way down. We’ve got to push the streptokinase.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Too risky. Even if it dissolves the clot, she could still bleed out anyway.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s hemodynamically compromised.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s not good for the baby.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dad doesn’t care.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Embolcine 250,000 units.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: BP’s dropping. Pressers!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We don’t have time. We’ve gotta suck it out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Systolic BP’s 80. BP’s stabilizing, O2 stats rising.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you get the clot?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I think so. She’s stabilized.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How long was her oxygen at that level?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ten minutes?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Brain function compromised?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: BP’s dropping. Up the dopamine. She’s not responding. How much?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s up to 30 micrograms!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Is she septic?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s bleeding into her abdomen.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We won’t be able to stop it. I’ll go talk to the husband.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you stay here. Keep her as stable as you can for as long as you can. She had trauma during the procedure. She’s bleeding into her abdomen. There’s nothing we can do; I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Um, no.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need you to okay the C-section.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s gonna kill her, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It probably will.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: I can’t do that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s dying either way.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I’m –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stay with me, Sean. I need your okay on this.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: She makes the decisions, and I’m –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, and that’s gonna be tough from now on, but this decision is easy. You know what she’d want.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: I can’t do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You make this call, only two things change. One: yeah, you feel guilty for killing your wife. Two: your baby lives. Naomi’s baby lives.

utterance.speaker: Sean
utterance.content: Okay, okay.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: He’s out; umbilical cord’s clamped.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No respiration.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His lungs aren’t opening up.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: They aren’t mature.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Come on, take a breath. You know you can do it. What’ve you got?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Looks like v-fib.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pulse?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: No. Paddles!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Come on, come on.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Clear!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Charging.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Come on, open up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How’s he doing?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He’s still not breathing; we’ve got to intubate.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Clear!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thank you. I’m late for the board meeting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don’t want to hear it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s about a patient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The pregnant woman? She wasn’t qualified for that trial and I’m not going to apologize –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not talking about her. At this point I think it’s best that I concentrate on patients who are still alive. Pulmonary embolism. She bled out. Saved her son. This is Olive Kaplan’s CT scan, the incredible shrinking baby.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Her thymus gland –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: DiGeorge Syndrome. It’s genetic, can cause the gland to wither to nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is why she couldn’t gain weight.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’ll call the police and Social Services and have all the charges withdrawn.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve sent a test down to confirm; when it comes back you should start Olive on immunoglobulin replacement.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re not going to do it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I assume I won’t be here.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your boy’s doing good.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: It’s the same motion as yesterday, people, same reasons. All those in favor of dismissing Gregory House raise a hand. Dr. Cuddy, you realize this is going to happen.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I can’t do it.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: You can’t abstain.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m not abstaining, I’m voting no.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: You’ve changed your mind since yesterday? What did he do, buy you dinner and roses? Threaten to drown your dog?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He did his job.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Right. He saved another life.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Maybe.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Good for him. It’s great. It’s not the point.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s what we do.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: And you could do it a lot better if you didn’t have to worry about some madman running around the hospital accountable to no one!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: But that’s not the choice you’re giving us.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: House won’t listen to anyone –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And you’re not accountable to anybody, either! Because you think you own us.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I move for the immediate dismissal of Dr. Lisa Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If you think House deserves to go, if you think I deserve to go, Wilson deserved to go, then vote yes. But if you’re doing this because you are afraid of losing his money, then he’s right! He does own you. You have a choice. Maybe the last real one you’ll have here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy is a genius, convincing four people to give up a fortune to save our sorry asses. Dr. Cuddy! The man of the hour.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re drinking. I would have thought that was pretty obvious.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, to the great champion. Saved you, saved Wilson, saved the whole team. Of course, none of them would have needed saving if you could actually get along with another human being.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, thank you, Miss Buzzkill.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, you only cost us $100 million. Could have saved some lives, could have made a few jobs, helped a few people. Yippee.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You voted to get rid of him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The lesser of two evils. You should be mourning. I know I am.
